awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: New Statistical Learning for Complex Heterogeneous Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on several important and challenging issues concerning complex heterogeneous data that arise from medical imaging and social networks. The major goals are to develop powerful and innovative statistical machine learning methods and tools that are able to flexibly model signal heterogeneity across images, integrate imaging data with multimodal and spatially distributed data, and tackle heterogeneity of network data. The integrated program of research and education will have significant impacts in many different fields such as biomedical studies, genomic research, environmental studies, public health research, and social and political sciences, among others. The project will also stimulate interdisciplinary research and collaboration with scientists from disparate fields.

This project will lead to substantial advancement in heterogeneity learning and modeling through exploiting individual variation from the general population, and integration of multiple sources of imaging information to enhance prediction accuracy for disease diagnoses and treatment outcomes. In addition, this project develops innovative unsupervised learning methods through utilizing node covariate information for analyzing heterogeneous network data. Each component of the research plan contains a broad range of topics, from methodological and computational development to applications in real world problems. Specifically, the PIs study subject-variant scalar-on-image regression models to incorporate the heterogeneity variation for brain imaging data, multi-dimensional tensor learning methods for breast cancer imaging data, flexible Gaussian graphical models for network data, and a novel clustering framework for heterogeneous data that are linked by networks. Furthermore, the development of advanced optimization techniques, algorithms and computational technologies will be applicable to many practical problems arising from large-scale heterogeneous data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on several important and challenging issues concerning complex heterogeneous data that arise from medical imaging and social networks. Recent advances in computing and measurement technologies have led to an explosion in the amount of data that are being collected in all areas of application. Much of these data have complex structure, in the form of text, images, video, audio, streaming data, and so on. This project focuses on one important class of problems, viz, data with network structures. Such data are common in diverse engineering and scientific areas, such as biology, computer science, electrical engineering, economics, sociology and so on.

There are two elementary components in all networks: a) nodes (basic units of a system) and b) the edges (connections between the nodes). These can differ widely depending on the applications. For example, the nodes might be humans or scientists in social networks; molecules, genes, or neurons in biology; routers or transformers in infrastructural networks; and web pages or research publications in information networks. Similarly, the edges might be friendships, alliances, reactions, synapses, optical and copper cables, URLs, or citations. The totality of the nodes and the edges defines a network, often represented in graphic form as a connectivity matrix, telling us which nodes are directly connected to each other.

Research on data with network structures has steadily increased in recent years, and they have appeared in leading science journals, such as Nature, Science and PNAS. While there has been extensive research on networks (primarily outside the field of Statistics), much of it deals with characterizing and modeling network structures using link information only. The scope of this project is different from much of the previous literature. Instead of trying to identify principles underlying the network structure, our work exploit the network structure as additional information and develop statistical theory and methods that take into account the structure of relationships between the data. Overall, the scientific objective of this project is to contribute to network research by developing novel statistical theory and methods for analyzing data with network structures. Specifically, the PI has made contributions in the following research areas: a) community detection, where we develop flexible models and scalable algorithms to fit large-scale networks; b) analysis of multiplex networks, where we develop latent space models for multiple, heterogeneous networks observed on a shared node set; c) analysis of network data with high-dimensional node variables, where we utilize graphical models and joint latent space models to study network data along with observed high-dimensional node variable; d) statistical learning on networks, in which a network with a set of nodes and edges is given, and we consider to develop a unified framework for some important statistical learning problems, e.g. regression, classification and survival analysis.

The project has also contributed to the training and development of future researchers and data analysts (including both statisticians and researchers outside statistics who analyze data). The PI has supervised six undergraduate students for research, mainly through an honors thesis program. Several PhD students have worked with the PI on various projects related to the proposal for thesis supervision, and they have gained experience and training in an important area of modern statistics and have learned the tools necessary for them to continue as independent researchers in the future. These students have taken research positions in industry including Google, Microsoft, Amazon, or are in tenure track positions at leading research universities including University of Virginia, Carnegie Mellon University, and University of Waterloo. The PI has also worked closely with researchers in other fields such as health sciences and environmental sciences and produced application articles in subject-matter journals, demonstrating the broad impact of the research.
